headline: CNN Newsroom
subHeadline: Alex Murdaugh Faces Day Two of Cross-Examination. Aired 10- 10:30 am ET

utterances.speaker: ALEX MURDAUGH, MURDER DEFENDANT
utterances.sentences: I remember lying to Tony Satterfield. And I remember looking him in the eye on many occasions.

utterances.speaker: CREIGHTON WATERS, PROSECUTOR
utterances.sentences: And lying to him?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: Yeah.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: Lying to his family?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: I lied to his family. I don't know if I did it in-person. But I know I had phone conversations with him where I lied to him.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: Let's talk a little bit about the pills, if we can.

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: OK.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: And you've already testified, as other people that you were still able to function as a lawyer over the years despite the pills that you were using. Is that correct?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: Yes, sir.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: And you were able, of course, during this period of time to engage in these relatively complicated setups that increased over the years that we've just talked about, despite the pill usage, is that correct?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: I was.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: Mm?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: I was.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: All right. And you were also able to -- during this time period, convince your staff that nothing was a mess with all of these exhibits, despite your pill usage?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: I mean, most of those didn't require convincing my staff, but just so we're on the same page, again, I acknowledge that I certainly allowed them to be misled, I certainly allowed them to do things that I shouldn't have done on my behalf knowing that they trusted me.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: How many -- how many pills were you using a day? MURDAUGH

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: OK, well, let's -- let's talk about -- let's say start maybe in January of 2021, and move forward. Can you describe to the jury what your daily pill intake was like?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: I think at that time, most of what I was purchasing was 30 milligram pills, instant release, oxycodone. That probably mixed in with some oxycontin, which is made of oxycodone is just time release. I would have been taken -- anywhere from 1500 milligrams, maybe to -- maybe -- maybe 1000 or -- maybe 1000 milligrams, or 1200 milligrams on a day, I didn't take as much or didn't have as much up to, I mean, there are days -- many days, a lot of days, most days were more than that, and many days would be, you know, 20 -- more than 2000 milligrams a day.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: How many pills is that?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: It depends on the strength.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: I'd say it's 30s that you just mentioned?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: If I took 30 -- if -- if I had 30 milligram pills -- you figure 100 pills would be 3000 milligrams.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: So you're taking 60 a day or something like that? I mean?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: There were days where I took more than that. There were days I took less than that.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: And how would you take them during the course of the day? I mean, how many have you taken at one time? How frequent in this time period and let's say January to June?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: You know, there's a point in time and I'm not sure when it was. I think it was well before that where -- and you have to understand this. This is something that I didn't -- I mean, I can still remember the first time I ever took an oxycontin.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: Mr. Murdaugh, can I ask you to answer my question and I'll let you explain all you want. My question was, how many were you taking a day during this time from January to June? Answer that first, please? And if you want to explain I'm happy to let you do so.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: All right, can you give -- give me one -- one example of a day during that time period?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: Sure.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: I mean, just you take -- start at eight o'clock in the morning, or whatever time you got up and take one and then one every 30 minutes. I mean --

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: Well, no, it --

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: I'm given you a chance to explain now.

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: It will totally depend -- it would totally depend on any number of circumstances. So starting a day, one of the main things that this would depend on was how late the day before I had taken pills, and how many I had taken. And did I take them during the night? Did I wake up during the night? And take them. So, you know, let's just say that it had been a while since I took any and I slept and I woke up, all right. Then, I would immediately -- immediately first thing take pills, because it was been a while, a lot of times, if you slept and hadn't taken pills, you'd wake up and you could tell the beginnings of those -- and I would say they were really withdrawals, but the agitation that you feel when you don't take and you could tell it so you had to take it right away. And so I would start off, first thing I would do would take pills.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: And that's how strong the withdrawals are for opiates, correct, that you feel that agitation until you can take another pill?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: Yes, I mean that but that -- I mean, that's just agitations, the tip of the iceberg when it comes to withdrawals, opiate withdrawals.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: I think you said in your last play for the jury, and the telephone conversation with Special Agent Kelly, that -- and you talked about withdrawal is just how strong they are, how you're willing to do anything to make him stop, correct?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: I think when I said is almost anything. WATERS

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: How many time you try to self-detox?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: Mr. Waters, dozens, dozens, if not hundreds. You know, there's so many I can't tell you.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: And those -- those symptoms you just described are extremely powerful, and made it very difficult to do that, is that correct?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: Made it difficult to?

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: To try to self-detox?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: Oh, it is extremely hard.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: You mentioned yesterday that you are paranoid, how long has that been going on?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: Well, no, I didn't say that I was paranoid. What I said was, as the addiction evolved, there would be situations where you would have these paranoid thoughts.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: And when did those first start?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: I can't tell you when they first started. But --

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: I mean, how long before June of 2021?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: Oh, a long time.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: A week, a month, a long time? MURDAUGH

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: How long do you have these paranoid thoughts?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: Usually a matter of seconds. I mean, it was something -- again, my whole life. You wouldn't see me where I didn't have pills on me. And that's where I kept them. I kept them on me because I was scared to put them somewhere for fear somebody would find them. So I've kept them on me. So if you saw me I had pills on me. I had a pocket full of pills on June 8 -- on June 8, when -- when I was sitting in -- in David Owens' patrol car. So I always had them on me. And I might turn -- I might be going to Edisto and I turn on Hampton Street right out here. And a police car pulls out. Boom, I had paranoid thoughts. You know it just -- but I could always say you're not doing -- you're not doing anything wrong. He's not following you and I can get past it in a matter of seconds.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: Did anybody in your family ever see you having these severe withdrawals?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: Absolutely.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: WATERS

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: Mags, Pawpaw, Bus, my dad, Randy, John Marvin. And just to be clear, Randy and John Marvin never saw me having withdrawals before September. They saw me --

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: And I thank you for clarifying that. Prior to June 2021, who and your family saw you having these severe withdrawals?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: Bus, Pawpaw, Maggie, my dad.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: Do you remember in calling -- remember calling, Paul a little detective?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: I don't know that I ever called him a little detective. But I think Maggie did. I may have. I mean Paul was very intuitive. So I heard Marian --(CROSSTALK)

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: And you said that during your interviews?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: I heard Marian call him a little detective. I know Maggie used to call him that.

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: Um, well, yeah it had something to do with it but I mean Paul was always that way but that -- that what led him to be called a little detective, certainly. There were times when -- when Paul found pills.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: Including just a month before the murders, is that correct?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: No, sir.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: You recall 6523 that was entered into evidence which is attacks from Paul to you?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: I did.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: What you said that Maggie found pills in your back?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: Right.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: Tell me about what happened after that?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: You asked me about Paul finding them, but it was Maggie that found them.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: Fair enough. So it was Maggie who found?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: Yes, sir.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: OK, but Paul's the one who reached out to you, correct?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: On that occasion, yes, sir.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: And what was the discussion after that?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: I can't remember exactly what it was. But it was about it. I had had eye surgery. The -- I don't know what day it was. But days before that, the day Maggie found them, Maggie drove me to the doctor for me to have my cataract removed, whatever -- late, whatever they call that surgery. I can't remember. But I had a cataract taken out, outpatient. You go in for a couple hours and you come out. And it was during COVID and so Maggie wasn't allowed to come into the doctor's office. And so she sat in the car and had left pills in a computer bag. And sitting out there bored, I guess she started looking at my computer and found them in the computer bag. So she found those pills.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: All right. And so she obviously told Paul and Paul texted you, correct? About finding those pills?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: That's correct.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: In May of 2021?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: That's correct.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: And you've heard your sister-in-law Marian testify that Maggie called him a little detective about the pills. You heard that testimony in this courtroom?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: I did hear that.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: All right. So did they start to watch you like a hawk and get on you about your pill usage during the month of May?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: No.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: They did not?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: No. Mr. Waters, this battle that I had with addiction it had been going on for years, years. And so they had been watching me like a hawk for years before May. May was just one occurrence where I let them down again.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: All right. They had been watching like a hawk for years, is that correct?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: About my pill addiction, yes, sir. That is correct.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: This time in May that wasn't the only time that Paul found pills or Maggie found pills, was that correct?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: No, there were a number of times where Mags found pills, Pawpaw found pills. Bus found pills. I mean, it was ongoing -- it was just an ongoing battle for me.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: And after they found those pills in May, that'd be a Maggie and Paul, were they trying to get you to self-detox?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: No, sir, not at that point in time.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: They just let it go?

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: Now you're claiming that about the time in May that -- that Paul talked to Maggie and not sure of that? Are you talking about a different time?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: I'm not claiming that Mr. Waters, that's a fat, this is what happened.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: All right, we're hearing that now. Correct?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: Hearing what now?

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: What you just said?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: Well, you just asked me this. Mr. Waters, you keep making the issue about the first time I -- you hearing these things, when -- when I got arrested and I went down, reaching out to you to talk to you about all of these things to try to tell you everything that I've done, to give you all these details, to help y'all go through these financial things. And up until the time that y'all charged me with murder and my wife and child, you would never give Jim Griffin response to our invitations to sit down and meet with you. So --

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: So you're telling me, I never responded to Jim Griffin, was that what you're saying here today?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: I'm telling you --

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: Are you saying that you ever before yesterday reached out to anyone through yourself or through your attorneys and reached out anyone in law enforcement of the prosecution and told them the story about the kennels? Are you telling me that?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: I'm -- what I'm telling you --

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: Answer my question first, please, sir. Answer my question first. Did you ever reach out to anyone in law enforcement or the prosecution and tell that story that you told this jury yesterday about the kennels before yesterday? It was you --

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: To say I want to tell you about the kennels? No sir, I did not.JIM GRIFFIN, ALEX MURDAUGH'S ATTORNEY: This questioning about on these charges violates his fifth amendment anymore. We have to make a motion.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: You brought up.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Objections overruled.

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: What I did was --(CROSSTALK)

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: Here's my question --

utterances.speaker: GRIFFIN
utterances.sentences: Yeah, right, he did not bring -- he was talking about financial stuff.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Sit down Mr. Griffin.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: Yes or no question. Before yesterday, did you ever bring up what you told the story about that kennels to anybody in the prosecution or anybody in law enforcement?

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: OK.

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: And never, never ever got a response to the multiple requests --

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: Multiple requests?

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: Yes, sir. Multiple requests, I would ask about this --

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: Mr. Murdaugh --

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Let's stop this, Sir.

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: Sir?

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: Did Mark Ball ever hear your story to the jury about the kennels until yesterday? Your buddy and law partner, Mark Ball.

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: I haven't spoken to Mark Ball since I went to rehab.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: And these were the same all partners that you were listening to the night of, is that -- is that what you testified to this jury earlier? You testified to that earlier, did you not?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: I don't understand your questions.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: Did you testified earlier that you were listening to your law partners on the night of the incident?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: Did -- was I listening to them?

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: Yeah. You testify to that, simple question, sir.

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: No. I'm sure I was it. When are you talking about?

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: On June 8 in the early morning hours, you testified to this jury that you were listening to them but you never told them the kennel story either. And they heard it for the first time yesterday as well. Isn't that correct?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: Yes, that's the first time they heard that.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: First time that Ronnie Crosby ever heard that, would have been yesterday?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: If he was listening that would have been the first time he heard it.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: First time John Harper (ph) hear that was yesterday?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: First time Danny Henderson who was representing you in the boat case ever heard that was yesterday?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: Yes, yesterday is the first time that I have said that openly. But that's not what you asked me Mr. Waters. But go ahead.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: First time your brother Randy heard that was yesterday?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: If he was listening.

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: And Mr. Waters, just to be clear, I was begging for a meeting with y'all to try to bring this to a close to talk me all about everything up until the time that y'all charged me with hurt and Maggie and Paul. Now, after that point in time, I stopped obviously --

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: You're discussing that you were begging for a meeting. And the -- but you admit, the information was never conveyed, that you wanted to change your story after multiple interviews with law enforcement about what happened that night, including the most important fact of all, which is when the last time you supposedly saw your wife and son lab was.

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: I don't know exactly what was conveyed or not. Because to you because I wasn't part of it. All I know is what --

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: Fair enough, you don't --

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: I was trying to do, was to sit down. I understood, bring all this to a close that y'all would want me to sit down and go through all of these financial things, all of these things that I've done wrong. And to try to bring that to a close, I was repeatedly trying to sit down with y'all.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: The reality is Mr. Murdaugh is the reason why no one's ever heard that before, is because you had sit in this courtroom and hear your family and your friends one after the other come in and testify that you were on that kennel video. So you like you've done so many times over the course of your life had to back up and make a new story that kind of fit with the facts that can't be denied. Isn't that true, sir?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: No, sir, that's not true.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: You've done that over and over again over the years with all of this that we've been talking about, haven't you?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: Done what over and over again?

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: The second that you're confronted with facts that you can't deny? You immediately come up with a new lie, doesn't that correct?
